heisig_chinese_memo: The fat king taking up the whole space under the umbrella actually isn't fat - he just has two big gold bars hidden under his clothes.
heisig_constituent: gold, metal, gold, umbrella, drop, king, jewel, ball, drop2
heisig_story: If this were not one of the most common characters you will ever have to write, I would apologize for having to give the explanation that follows. Anyway, we want to depict bars of gold bullion with an umbrella overhead to shade them from the heat (and perhaps to hide them as well). The bullion is made by melting down all the scepters of the kingdom, drop by drop, and shaping them into bars.
koohiiStory1: The fat king taking up the whole space under the umbrella actually isnÂ´t fat - he just has two big gold bars hidden under his clothes.
koohiiStory2: Under the umbrellaÂ´s shade, the king sang, " Drop it to the left, drop it to the right, give me all the GOLD in sight!".

origin_of_ch_char_book: The monument features the three supreme existences of the Universe: Heaven (å¤©), Earth(åœ°), and Human (äºº)â€” and the five basic elements of the universe: water(æ°´), fire(ç«), iron (é‡‘), wood(æœ¨), soil(åœŸ) (14th-19th century) ,The ancient Chinese considered that there were five essential elements in the universe: Water (æ°´, shui), Fire (ç«, huo), Wood (æœ¨, mu), Iron (é‡‘, jin), and Earth (åœŸ, tu). The five main elements interact and create each other or restrain each other. For example, the tree burns and creates fire which burns down to ashes and becomes earth (soil). Water restrains fire and fire can melt metal. (äº”, wu, five) contains such philosophical meanings. The top line means sky , the bottom line is earth , and the middle shows how the â€œfive elementsâ€ cross and interact with each other.,(é‡‘, jin, gold; metal) has a lid covering the top of the object and something under it (ä»Š, jin, now), and a soil beneath it (åœŸ, tu, soil), and some points dotted around them . As a whole, this character means gathering the shiny particles that are contained in the soil. It originally meant various metals contained in the soil, but later it came to mean gold.

Anyway, we want to depict bars of gold bullion with an umbrella overhead to shade them from the heat (and perhaps to hide them as well). The bullion is made by melting down all the scepters of the kingdom, drop by drop, and shaping them into bars.
* As a primitive, it means not only gold but any metal at all.

gold
Basic explanation of words
gold
jÄ«n
A chemical element, symbol Au, atomic number 79, yellow-red, soft: gold. Gold. Gold pen.
A general term for solids such as gold that are shiny, ductile, easy to transfer heat and conduct electricity (except for mercury). :metal. Hardware (old refers to gold, silver, copper, iron and tin). Alloy (a metal that is a mixture of two or more metals). Jin Wen (an inscription cast or engraved on Shang and Zhou bronzes, formerly known as "Zhong Ding Wen").
Money: cash. fund. Spend money like dirt.
Refers to weapons or metal musical instruments: gold leather (general term for weapon armor, extended to refer to war). Golden sound (a. Zheng sound; b. Bell sound). Golden drums (gongs and drums).
One of the ancient Chinese musical instrument octave.
Yu noble, precious, rare, durable, strong, shiny, etc.: Jinlan (deep friendship). King Kong (Sanskrit paraphrase, Yu is firm, sharp, and capable of destroying everything). Jin Ou (a. Wine container; b. Yu territory is complete). Jincheng Tangchi.
Some animals and plants get their name because they resemble gold in color: goldfish. Golden Crow (Sun). Beetle. Golden monkey.
Chinese dynasty name: Jin Dynasty.
name.
gold
Chinese dictionary definition of words
[â‘ ]ï¼»jÄ«nï¼½
["Guangyun" Ju Yinqie, flat invasion, see. ]
(1) The name of the chemical element. The symbol Au. The color is red and yellow, soft in quality, malleable, and stable in chemical properties. It is a kind of precious metal, used to make currency, decorations and so on. Commonly known as gold or gold.
(2) General term for metals.
(3) The metaphor is strong. See "Golden City".
(4) Bell and Ding made of bronze or pure copper.
(5) Refers to a musical instrument used as a signal in the military.
(6) Refers to knocking Zheng.
(7) Instruments of torture. Knife, saw, axe and the like.
(8) Weapons. Swords and so on.
(9) Weapons. arrow.
(10) Golden Seal.
(11) Refers to gold ornaments.
(12) The tip of the ploughshare.
(13) Refers to the bronze tiger symbol. See "Golden Bamboo".
(14) A belt inlaid with gold.
(15) Gold thread.
(16) Money; currency.
(17) The unit of calculation of currency. During the Warring States Period and the Qin Dynasty, one silver was used as one gold, and one gold was twenty taels.
(18) The unit of calculation of currency. In the Han Dynasty, one catty was regarded as one gold.
(19) Calculate the unit of currency. In the Song Dynasty, one coin was used as one gold.
(20) Calculate the unit of currency. From the Ming Dynasty to modern times, one or two silver or one silver coin was used as one gold.
(21) The color like gold.
(22) It is a metaphor for precious things.
(23) Metaphor is precious. See "Jinke Jade Bar".
(24) Refers to wheat rust
